summary: 01/01/2012: A grenade was thrown into a shop on Joint Road, Quetta city, Balochistan province, Pakistan. Twelve people were injured in the blast, and damage was done to a number of nearby shops. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
propcomment: The targeted shops, as well as several other shops in the area, were damaged in this attack.
addnotes: There is doubt that this incident meets terrorism-related criteria. Given the political and criminal context in Pakistan, the attack on the shop may have been the result of local crime. However, given the high number of casualties, a political motive cannot be dismissed.
scite1: "16 hurt in hand grenade attacks in Quetta, Hub," Daily The Post, January 3, 2012.
scite2: "Grenade attack injures five in Quetta," Daily The Post, January 2, 2012.
scite3: "Grenade attack injures nine in Quetta," Plus News Pakistan, January 2, 2012.

summary: 01/01/2012: Assailants threw two grenades and opened fire on Locus Pub as people were celebrating the new year in Garissa city, North Eastern region, Kenya. This was one of two attacks on bars just after midnight on January 1, 2012 in Garissa. Across the two attacks, five people were killed and 28 injured. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources suspected Al-Shabaab.
motive: The specific motive is unknown; however, Al-Shabaab had vowed to retaliate against Kenya for crossing the border into Somalia to attack them in October 2011.
weapdetail: Two grenades and AK-47 assault rifles were used in the attack.
propcomment: The dance floor was damaged in this attack.
addnotes: Casualty numbers for this attack represent an equal division of a cumulative total of killed and wounded across incidents 201201010002 and 201201010004. Casualty numbers for this incident conflict across sources. Following GTD protocol, the majority estimates are reported here.
scite1: "BRIEF: Five killed in   grenade attack   in northern Kenya," DPA (Berlin), January 1, 2012.
scite2: "UPDATE 2-Gunmen attack bars in northeast Kenya, 5 dead," Reuters News, January 1, 2012.
scite3: "Gunmen attack bars in northeast Kenya, at least 2 dead," Plus News Pakistan, January 2, 2012.

propcomment: The victim's vehicle was damaged in this attack.

scite3: "4 FC men killed in Dera Bugti blast," The Nation, January 2, 2012.

summary: 01/01/2012: Assailants attacked a Congolese village in Shabunda territory, South Kivu province, Democratic Republic of the Congo. The Democratic Front for the Liberation of Rwanda (FDLR) claimed responsibility for the incidents, stating that they were in revenge for locals allying themselves with Raia Mutomboki, a local defense group.

motive: The attack by the Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda was in revenge for locals allying themselves with Raia Mutomboki, a local defense group.
propcomment: Six houses were damaged in this attack.

summary: 01/05/2012: Assailants detonated a remote-controlled landmine near a police vehicle in Badarpanga area, Odisha state, India. No group claimed responsibility, but authorities attributed the attack to Maoists.

propcomment: The beer parlor was damaged in this attack.

summary: 01/10/2012: Assailants attacked the Telecommunications Ministry building in Sharan city, Paktika province, Afghanistan. At least three people were also hurt in the attack. The Taliban claimed responsibility for the incident.

summary: 01/10/2012: Assailants threw a grenade at the home of Trinamul Congress candidate K. Joykishen in Imphal city, Manipur state, India. Seven people were injured in the attack. No group claimed responsibility, but sources attributed the attack to members of People's Revolutionary Party of Kangleipak (PREPAK). Joykishen was a former member of PREPAK who had disobeyed the mandate of the group that no former member was allowed to contest elections.
motive: The specific motive is unknown; however, the target was a former member of the People's Revolutionary Party of Kangleipak (PREPAK) who had disobeyed the mandate of the group that no former member was allowed to contest elections.
propcomment: It is unknown if any property was damaged in this attack.

summary: 01/10/2012: A tanker for the Guwahati Oil Refinery exploded and caught fire in Noonmati suburb, Assam state, India. Seven workers were wounded in the explosion. The United Liberation Front of Asom (ULFA) claimed responsibility for the attack, stating that it was carried out in retaliation for the exploitation of Assam's natural resources by the Indian government. However, refinery authorities said the blast was a result of an accident.
motive: The United Liberation Front of Assam (ULFA) claimed responsibility and stated that the attack was in retaliation for the exploitation of Assam's natural resources by the Indian government.
propcomment: A tanker at the Guwahati Refinery and its surroundings were damaged in this attack.
addnotes: There is doubt that this incident meets terrorism-related criteria. While the United Liberation Front of Assam (ULFA) did claim responsibility, officials instead claimed that the fire was caused by technical difficulties and not the result of an intentional attack.
scite1: "SEVEN INJURED IN ASSAM REFINERY FIRE," Hindustan Times, January 11, 2012.
scite2: "Separatist group torches refinery in northeast India," Xinhua General News Service, January 10, 2012.

summary: 01/11/2012: Approximately 100 assailants attacked an Administration police camp near Gerille town, North Eastern province, Kenya. The attackers used machine guns and grenades in their attack, killing six people, injuring six, and taking three hostage. One of the hostages was released on January 20, 2013; the remaining two hostages were released on or around July 31, 2013. In a video message claiming responsibility, Al-Shabaab declared a "jihad" on Kenya for waging war against Somalia.
motive: Al-Shabaab declared a "jihad" on Kenya for waging war against Somalia.  The attack on the police camp was a manifestation of Al-Shabaab's campaign.
weapdetail: Machine-guns were used in the attack.
propcomment: The police camp was damaged in this attack.
addnotes: Casualty numbers for this incident conflict across sources. Following GTD protocol, the most recent estimates are reported here. In addition, three hostages were taken. One of the hostages, was released on January 20th while the status of the other two remains unknown.
scite1: "Somali Islamists say kill soldier, delay executions," Reuters, February 14, 2013.
scite2: "UPDATE 2-Al Shabaab attack Kenyan police camp, kill 7," Reuters News, January 12, 2012.
scite3: "SOMALIA: REBELS ATTACK KENYA," The New York Times Abstracts, January 13, 2012.

summary: 01/16/2012: Five explosive devices were found and defused on Nepalgunj-Gulariya road, Banke district, Mid-Western Region, Nepal. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, a pamphlet and flag belonging to the Janatantrik Tarai Madhes Mukti Party were found at the scene.

weapdetail: Three socket bombs and a sutli firecracker were used in the attack.
addnotes: The bomb disposal squad defused three socket bombs, a time bomb, and a Sutali bomb.
scite1: "NA defuses explosives in Banke," Himalayan Times, January 16, 2012.
scite2: "Bomb scare in Banke," Himalayan Times, January 16, 2012.

location: Incident occurred along the Kongba riverbank.
summary: 01/16/2012: A remote-controlled explosive device went off near the house of P. Premananda, a Trinamool Congress candidate, in Kongba riverbank, Naharup area, Manipur state, India. No one was injured in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources noted that Congress members had been continuously attacked leading up to the January 28, 2012 elections.
motive: The specific motive is unknown; however, Indian National Congress members were continuously attacked leading up to the January 28, 2012 elections.
scite1: "Militants attack Trinamool Congress candidate's house," The Press Trust of India Limited, January 16, 2012.
scite2: "Trinamool candidate 'threatens' Chief Electoral Officer," Tehelka (India), January 17, 2012.
scite3: "Rebels target candidates," The Telegraph, January 17, 2012.

summary: 01/16/2012: Armed people attacked a unit of the Assam Rifles in Jhoukhonom area, Churachandpur district, Manipur state, India. The attackers killed two Rifles, injured two, and stole a rifle. A joint committee, including The People's Revolutionary Party of Kangleipak (PREPAK), People's Liberation Army (India), and the Revolutionary People's Front, claimed responsibility for the incident.
motive: The specific motive is unknown; however, sources speculated that the attackers wanted to disrupt the upcoming polls in Manipur on January 28, 2012.
scite1: "India: Two Indian Army personnel killed in Manipur," Thai News Service, January 19, 2012.
scite2: "CorCom ambushes AR patrol, two weapons taken away," Imphal Free Press, January 16, 2012.

summary: 01/16/2012: Assailants attacked a North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) supply convoy in Deh Sheikh wa Parwana area, Injil district, Herat province, Afghanistan. Three oil tankers were destroyed in the attack, but no one was injured. No group claimed responsibility, but sources attributed the incident to the Taliban.
corp1: North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO): International Security Assistance Force (ISAF)
propcomment: Three fuel supply vehicles were damaged in this attack.
scite1: "Taliban destroy three NATO fuel tankers," Afghan Islamic Press (AIP), January 17, 2012.
scite2: "Taleban destroy three NATO fuel tankers in Afghan west," Afghan Islamic Press, January 17, 2012.

summary: 01/16/2012: An explosive device was found and defused on Shahi road, Darbar-e-Hussainia Imambargah, Punjab province, Pakistan. The explosive device was placed near the location of a suicide bombing on January 15, 2012. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

summary: 01/16/2012: Gunmen shot and killed three builders from Chad in Pompomari area near Damaturu area, Yobe state, Nigeria. The attackers first robbed the victims of their cell phones and then shot them without provocation. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

summary: 01/16/2012: Three explosive devices went off in the Equitalia tax agency office in Corso Meridionale near Naples railway station, Naples city, Campania region, Italy. No one was injured in the attack, but the building was damaged. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources noted that Equitalia had been attacked before because many Italians suspected it of strongarming people into paying taxes.

summary: 01/16/2012: Assailants attacked the Sumifru Banana Plantation in Mawab district, Compostela Valley province, Philippines. The gunmen first opened fire on security guards and then on army units coming as reinforcement. Six assailants were killed in the failed attack. No group claimed responsibility, but sources attributed the incident to the New People's Army (NPA). The NPA frequently targets mining, logging, and agricultural businesses that violate its policies.
motive: The specific motive is unknown; however, the New People's Army (NPA) frequently targets mining, logging, and agricultural businesses that violate its policies.
scite1: "6 NPAs killed in foiled attack," The Philippine Star, January 18, 2012.

location: Incident occurred near the Erta Ale camp on the volcano.
summary: 01/17/2012: Assailants attacked a group of tourists at the Erta Ale volcano in Afar region, Ethiopia. The assailants killed five European tourists and kidnapped two Ethiopians and two Germans. The Germans were released on March 6, 2012. The whereabouts of the Ethiopian victims are unknown. The Afar Revolutionary Democratic Unit Front (ARDUF) claimed responsibility for the incident.
motive: The specific motive is unknown; however, the group who carried out the attack is known for fighting against what they perceive as political and economic ignorance of the Afar region of Ethiopia.
addnotes: The two German nationals that were abducted in this attack were later released. The whereabouts of the two Ethiopian nationals who were also abducted in this attack remain unknown.
scite1: "Ethiopia deny claims by rebel group that their troops shot foreign tourists," Associated Press Newswires, January 24, 2012.
scite2: "Five Europeans killed in Ethiopia attack," Agence France Presse, January 18, 2012.
scite3: "UPDATE 2-Ethiopia says Eritrea-trained gunmen killed tourists," Reuters News, January 17, 2012.

location: Near the halfway point of the Cano Limon pipeline
summary: 01/17/2012: An explosive device detonated on the Cano Limon oil pipeline near its halfway point in an unknown location in Norte de Santander department, Colombia. No other information is available.

location: Incident occurred in the Karari area of the city.
summary: 01/17/2012: Assailants shot and killed Abba Kyari in Karari neighborhood, Maiduguri city, Borno state, Nigeria. Kyari had taken a gun away from a Boko Haram member and prevented an explosive device attack the previous day. Sources attribute the attack to Boko Haram, saying members of the group killed Kyari out of anger at his intervention.
motive: Boko Haram claimed responsibility for the attack and stated that they killed the victim out of anger at his courage in confronting a member the previous day.

One of the individuals was Communist Party of India (ML-Liberation) leader Akhtar Ansari. The kidnappers demanded the destruction of the Kone, Oreya, and Saryu police checkpoints in Latehar district. They also demanded the withdrawal of security members engaged in anti-Maoist operations in Jharkhand. The resolution of the kidnapping is unknown. No group claimed responsibiity, but sources attributed the incident to Maoists.
motive: The kidnappers demanded the destruction of the Kone, Oreya, and Saryu police checkpoints in Latehar district. They also demanded the withdrawal of security members engaged in anti-Maoist operations in Jharkhand.
addnotes: The four abducted individuals were Susma Mehta, Sunesh Ram, Ahmed, and Akhtar Ansari.

summary: 01/21/2012: Six gunmen in two vehicles opened fire on an Iraqi military checkpoint in Fallujah city, Al Anbar governorate, Iraq. Four soldiers were killed in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

summary: 01/21/2012: Assailants kidnapped a dual German-United States (US) citizen in Galkayo city, Mudug region, Somalia. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
motive: The specific motive is unknown; however, ransom kidnappings have become more common in Somalia in the last five years.

summary: 01/26/2012: Several explosive devices placed around the outside of two police officers' houses exploded in Musayib city, Babil governorate, Iraq. Ten people died, four were injured, and the houses were destroyed. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.

addnotes: The police officers targeted were identified as brothers Ahmed Zuwaiyin and Jihad Zuwaiyin. Casualty numbers for this incident conflict across sources. Following GTD protocol, the majority estimates are reported here.

summary: 01/26/2012: Assailants abducted Edgar Raupach on Zaria Road in Kano city, Kano state, Nigeria. Raupach was a German engineer working for Dantata & Sawoe Construction Company. The kidnappers demanded the release of Filiz Gelowicz, also known as Umm Sayf Allah Al-Ansariy. Raupach was shot and stabbed to death by his kidnappers during an attempted rescue operation on May 31, 2012. Al-Qa`ida in the Lands of the Islamic Maghreb (AQLIM) claimed responsibility for the incident. Sources also suspect that Boko Haram was behind the attack.

addnotes: The hostage was killed by the abductors when soldiers raided a house, unaware that the hostage was being kept there.

summary: 01/26/2012: A bus of 49 Iranian pilgrims was stopped by armed assailants near Halab area, Aleppo governorate, Syria. Eleven people on the bus were kidnapped. motive: The specific motive is unknown; however, a similar kidnapping the previous month was perpetrated because of Iran's support for the Syrian government.
addnotes: The kidnapped pilgrims were on route from Damascus to Aleppo.  The remaining people who were not kidnapped were robbed of their possessions.  Five of the 11 victims abducted in this attack were later released. The whereabouts of the remaining six hostages is unknown.

summary: 01/28/2012: Gunmen stopped a car carrying at least one customs official in Dashti Abadan area, Kunduz province, Afghanistan. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, an officer posited that local warlords had told customs officers there would be consequences if the warlords' illegal demands were not satisfied.
motive: The specific motive is unknown; however, an officer posited that local warlords had told customs officers there would be consequences if the warlords' illegal demands were not satisfied.
addnotes: Casualty numbers for this incident conflict across sources. Following GTD protocol, the lowest estimates are reported here.
scite1: "Kidnapped customs official recovered," Afghan Islamic Press (AIP), January 30, 2012.
scite2: "Customs official abducted in Kunduz," Afghan Islamic Press (AIP), January 29, 2012.
scite3: "One customs official   shot   dead, 3 kidnapped," Pajhwok Afghan News English, January 29, 2012.

summary: 01/26/2012: Gunmen attacked Indian National Congress employees in Namtaolong area, Tamenglong district, Manipur state, India. One person was killed and one injured in the attack. No group claimed responsibility, but sources attributed the attack to Zeliangrong United Front (ZUF) members, noting that it occurred two days before the statewide Congress elections.
motive: The specific motive is unknown; however, the attack on Indian National Congress workers came two days before the statewide Congress elections.
scite1: "2 CRPF jawans among three killed in rebel attacks," The Times of India, January 29, 2012.

motive: The specific motive is unknown; however, the device was discovered at a polling station on the same day as the statewide Congress elections.

summary: 01/28/2012: An explosive device detonated at the house of Asad Gul in Meri colony, Kohat district, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, Pakistan. Gul was a former Pakistani Army officer. summary: 01/28/2012: A sticky bomb placed on a soldier's car exploded in Tuz Khurmato town, Kirkuk, Iraq. Two people, including the soldier, were injured in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

summary: 01/28/2012: An explosion occurred on a bus in Garki area, Abuja state, Nigeria. There were no casualties in the incident. While some sources alleged that there were explosive canisters on the bus, official sources claimed that the explosion was an accident. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
propcomment: A bus was damaged in this attack.
addnotes: There is doubt that this incident meets terrorism-related criteria. Authorities claimed that the blast was not the result of an explosive device.
scite1: "Bus Laden With Explosives Goes Ablaze," Leadership (Abuja), January 29, 2012.

location: Two km from Williamnager, in East Garo Hills
summary: 01/28/2012: Assailants burned down the house of Andreas Momin in Bokkingre billage, East Garo Hills district, Meghalaya state, India. Momin was a former member of the Garo National Liberation Army (GNLA) who had turned in his weapons to police. No group claimed responsibility, but authorities attributed the attack to the GNLA, noting that the assailants had given Momin a week to refund them the value of the weapons.
motive: The Garo National Liberation Army (GNLA) burned the victim's house because he did not refund them the cost of the weapons he turned into the police.
propcomment: One house was damaged in this attack.
addnotes: The victim's family members were also chased away from the area.
scite1: "Indian Security Forces Kill 1 Rebel GNLA Cadre, Injure 5 in Meghalaya," The Telegraph Online, February 10, 2012.

summary: 01/29/2012: An assailant attacked a convoy of Ethiopian soldiers near Dhagax Bridge, Beledweyne town, Hiiraan Region, Somalia. An unknown number of troops were killed and injured in the attack. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the incident.
propcomment: The Ethiopian armed personnel vehiclerier was damaged in this attack.
addnotes: There is conflicting information on weapon type.
scite1: "Ethiopian troops targeted with explosion in central Somali town," Shabeelle Media Network website, Mogadishu, February 1, 2012.

summary: 01/28/2012: Four attackers on two motorcycles shot and killed a police officer on Shaikh Yousuf road, Dera Ismail Khan city, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, Pakistan. One of the assailants was wearing a suicide vest that was never detonated. The police then returned fire, killing one attacker and cornering the others in a private university. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
addnotes: The assailant that was killed had a suicide vest on.
scite1: "Pakistan: Bomber killed, cop martyred in DI Khan attack," Right Vision News, January 30, 2012.
scite2: "Cop, terrorist killed in terrorism bid," The Baluchistan Express, January 29, 2012.
scite3: "Cop, terrorist killed in DI Khan shootout," Daily Times, January 29, 2012.

summary: 01/29/2012: Assailants attacked 47 Chinese construction workers in South Kurdufan Region, Sudan. Seventeen workers escaped, one was shot and killed, and 29 were kidnapped in the attack. The group's president, Malik Agar, met with the Chinese ambassador to Ethiopia, demanding extra Red Cross humanitarian aid in the country. The hostages were released on February 7, 2012. No group claimed responsibility, but sources attributed the incident to members of the Sudan People's Liberation Movement: North.
motive: The attackers demanded extra Red Cross humanitarian aid in Sudan in exchange for the hostages.
ransomnote: The perpetrators demanded that China pressure the government of Sudan to allow humanitarian aid into the country's restive northern region in exchange for the release of the hostages.
addnotes: Fourteen of the 29 Chinese workers who were taken hostage in this attack were freed on 01/30/2012. The fate of the remaining 15 hostages is unknown.
scite1: "BRIEF: Sudanese   rebels   seize 29 Chinese workers," DPA (Berlin), January 29, 2012.
scite2: "Red Cross says 29 Chinese workers abducted by rebels in Sudan have been released," Associated Press Newswires, February 7, 2012.
scite3: "China: Body of missing worker recovered in Sudan," The Associated Press, February 7, 2012.

summary: 01/29/2012: An explosive device detonated near a police patrol in the primarily Shiite Al-Zafaraniyah neighborhood, Karadah district, Baghdad city, Baghdad governorate, Iraq. One person died and nine were injured in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
motive: The specific motive is unknown; however, extremists are considered to be exploiting tensions between Sunnis and Shiites in Iraq.  The attack occurred in a primarily Shiite neighborhood.
weapdetail: A roadside bomb was used in the attack.
propcomment: A police vehicle and civilian vehicle were damaged in this attack.
scite1: "Iraq officials: Baghdad   bomb blast   kills 1," Associated Press Online, January 29, 2012.
scite2: "FACTBOX-Security developments in Iraq, January 29," Reuters News, January 29, 2012.
scite3: "Iraqi officials say bomb in Baghdad Shiite neighbourhood kills 1," The Canadian Press - Broadcast wire, January 29, 2012.

summary: 01/29/2012: Assailants attacked Nayibawa Police Station with guns and explosive devices in Kano city, Kano state, Nigeria. The police fought back and waged a one-hour gunbattle. Two civilians died in the attack. An explosive device was also thrown inside the police station but did not detonate. No group claimed responsibility for the incident, but sources suspected Boko Haram.
motive: The specific motive is unknown; however, in a video released three days earlier, the leader of Boko Haram, Abubakar Shekau, threatened to attack more security personnel and accused Barack Obama of waging war with Islam.
propcomment: It is unknown if the police station was damaged in this attack.

motive: The specific motive is unknown; however, the location of the school bombing is situated close to Malakand Agency, where there had earlier been an operation named "Rah-e-Rast" to destroy girls' schools in the area.
weapdetail: Explosive devices weighing between eight and ten kilograms were used in the attack.

summary: 01/30/2012: An attacker shot and killed Major Kurban Akhmedov with an assault rifle in Chapayevo area, Kumtorkala district, Dagestan republic, Russia. Akhmedov was a senior police officer in the extremism department. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
target1: Extremism Department Operative: Major Kurban Akhmedov
weapdetail: An assault rifle was used in the attack.
propcomment: The victims' vehicle was damaged in this attack.
scite1: "Policeman killed in Dagestan," Russia & CIS Military Newswire, January 30, 2012.
scite2: "Policeman killed in Dagestan - source," Russia & CIS Military Newswire, January 30, 2012.

summary: 01/30/2012: Assailants shot and killed a guard at a church in Potiskum area, Yobe state, Nigeria. The guard was also a member of the Igbo tribe. No group claimed responsibility for the incident, but sources suspected Boko Haram.
weapdetail: Rifles were used in the attack.
scite1: "Gunmen in Northeastern Nigeria Shoot Two Christian Traders Dead," AFP (World Service), February 11, 2012.

summary: 01/30/2012: Maulvi Safiullah, a High Peace Council (HPC) member, was kidnapped in Asmar city, Kunar province, Afghanistan. He was released on February 26, 2012 near Asadabad. No ransom was paid to free the captive. A local Taliban commander claimed the kidnapping, stating that it was carried out to demand the release of Taliban members in prison.
motive: The kidnapping was perpetrated to demand the release of fellow rebels members in prison.
scite1: "Abducted HPC member released in Kunar," Pajhwok Afghan News English, February 26, 2012.

location: Incident occurred in the Jogi area of the Kurram Agency.
summary: 01/31/2012: At least 100 assailants attacked a strategic military checkpost in Jogi area, Kurram Agency, Federally Administered Tribal Areas, Pakistan. In the subsequent battle, 35 attackers were killed and 30 wounded, while eight soldiers were killed and 32injured. No group claimed responsibility for the incident, but sources suspected Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) and noted that the checkpoint was attacked because it was blocking Taliban movement from Tirah valley in Khyber Agency to Orakzai North Waziristan.
motive: The checkpoint was attacked because it was blocking Taliban movement from Tirah valley in Khyber Agency to Orakzai Agency and North Waziristan.
propcomment: It is unknown if any property was damaged in this attack.
addnotes: Casualty numbers for this incident conflict across sources. Following GTD protocol, the majority estimates are reported here.
scite1: "8 soldiers, 25 militants killed in Pak clash," The Press Trust of India Limited, January 31, 2012.
scite2: "Eight Pakistani soldiers killed in Taliban clashes," Agence France Presse, January 31, 2012.
scite3: "Militant attacks kill 8 Pakistani soldiers," CNN Wire, January 31, 2012.

summary: 01/31/2012: Gunmen shot at the car of Ali al-Amrani as he was leaving a cabinet meeting in Sanaa city, Amanat Al Asimah governorate, Yemen. Al-Amrani was Yemen's Minister of Information. No one was injured in the gunfire. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
corp1: Yemeni Ministry of Communications and Information Technology
propcomment: It is unknown if the minister's vehicle was damaged in this attack.
scite1: "UPDATE 7-Yemen minister eludes assassination attempt," Reuters News, January 31, 2012.
scite2: "US airstrikes kill 4 al-Qaida militants in Yemen," The Associated Press, January 31, 2012.
scite3: "UPDATE 1-Yemen minister escapes assassination attempt-aide," Reuters News, January 31, 2012.

location: Incident occurred 56 kilometers west of Sanaa.
summary: 01/31/2012: Four United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs workers and two drivers were kidnapped from a tourist location in Mahwait governorate, Yemen. The kidnapping tribe demanded the release of one of their members in custody. All six were returned unharmed on February 1, 2012.
corp1: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs
motive: The kidnapping was perpetrated demand the release of a fellow tribe member.  The hostages were purportedly released when the tribe member was exchanged.
addnotes: The six aid workers taken hostage were of Yemeni, German, Palestinian, Iraqi, and Colombian origin. They were released one day after being abducted after mediation efforts led by Energy Minister Saleh Samee were initiated.  A seventh hostage, apparently unrelated to the United Nations members, was released as well, according to one source.
scite1: "UPDATE 4-Seven aid workers in Yemen freed, U.N. says," Reuters News, February 2, 2012.
scite2: "Kidnapped foreign workers freed in Yemen: minister," Agence France Presse, February 1, 2012.
scite3: "UPDATE 7-Yemen minister eludes assassination attempt," Reuters News, January 31, 2012.

summary: 01/31/2012: A suicide bomber attacked the house of Abdi Hassan Awale Qeybid in Galkayo city, Mudug region, Somalia. Qeybid was a former warlord, police commander, and Minister of Mineral Resources. At the time, he was conducting a meeting with city politicians. Five people died in the attack, but not Qeybid. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the incident, stating that they carried it out because of Qeybid's opposition to Sharia law.
target1: Former Police Chief: Abdi Hasan Qeybdid
motive: Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the attack and stated that it was carried out because of the target's opposition to Sharia law.
propcomment: The front gate of the house was damaged in this attack.
addnotes: Casualty numbers for this incident conflict across sources. Following GTD protocol, the most recent estimates are reported here.
scite1: "UPDATE 2-Bomber targets ex-Somali police chief, kills two," Reuters News, January 31, 2012.
scite2: "Suicide bomber kills two in central Somalia attack: official," Agence France Presse, January 31, 2012.
scite3: "1 dead in Somalia after attempted assassination of formerly powerful wardlord," Associated Press Newswires, January 31, 2012.

location: Incident occurred in the North Nazimabad area of the city.
summary: 01/31/2012: Four assailants opened fire on a Telenor mobile phone store in North Nazimabad town, Karachi city, Sindh province, Pakistan. Two people died and three were injured in the gunfire. This was one of a spate of attacks on cell phone franchises in Pakistan. No group claimed responsibility for the incident, but sources suspected Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan (TTP).
motive: The specific motive is unknown; however, there has been a pattern of attacks on cell phone franchises in Pakistan.
weapdetail: Multiple 9mm pistols were used in the attack.
propcomment: It is unknown if Telenor's franchise was damaged in this attack.
scite1: "Fear grips Karachi as five more killed," Daily The Post, February 1, 2012.
scite2: "Another Telco Franchise Attacked, Third in One Month," Plus News Pakistan, January 31, 2012.
scite3: "Target killing: Two gunned down in cell phone office attack," Pakistan Press International, January 31, 2012.

location: In the limits of Bilal Colony, in Sector 5-D, near Power House
summary: 01/31/2012: Gunmen opened fire at a car of Muttahida Qaumi Movement (MQM) activists in the limits of Bilal Colony, Sector 5-D, New Karachi city, Sindh province, Pakistan. Three MQM members died in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
scite1: "MPA Domki's wife, daughter among three shot dead," Plus News Pakistan, January 31, 2012.
scite2: "Three MQM men gunned down," Business Recorder, January 31, 2012.
scite3: "Karachi tense as target killings claim four more lives," Daily Times, January 31, 2012.

summary: 01/31/2012: Assailants killed Taseer Abbas close to his house in Ancholi neighborhood, Federal B. Area, Sindh province, Pakistan. Abbas was part of Anjuman Tanzeem-i-Hussaini. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, the murder was thought to be sectarian in nature.
motive: The specific motive is unknown; however, the murder was thought to be sectarian in nature.
scite1: "MPA Domki's wife, daughter among three shot dead," Plus News Pakistan, January 31, 2012.

location: Near the Margat coalmines, east of Quetta
summary: 01/31/2012: Assailants attacked a Frontier Corps (FC) checkpoint near Margat coalmines, Quetta city, Balochistan province, Pakistan. This was one of four attacks on FC checkpoints in Balochistan on this date. Eighteen people were killed and 12 injured across the four attacks. In this particular attack, three FC soldiers were kidnapped and killed 33 days later after a kangaroo court found them guilty of torturing group members. A Baloch Liberation Army (BLA) spokesperson claimed that the attacks were in response to the killings of Nawab Akbar Bugti's granddaughter and great-granddaughter.
motive: A Baloch Liberation Army (BLA) spokesperson claimed that the attacks were in response to the killings of Nawab Akbar Bugti's granddaughter and great-granddaughter.
weapdetail: Sophisticated and small weapons were used in the attack.
addnotes: Casualty numbers for this incident conflict across sources. Following GTD protocol, the lowest estimates are reported here.
scite1: "3 paramilitary personnel abducted and killed by Baloch group," The Press Trust of India Limited, March 4, 2012.
scite2: "15 killed in Pakistan's southwest: officials," Agence France Presse -- English, February 1, 2012.
scite3: "11 Pakistani soldiers killed in southwest attacks: officials," Agence France Presse, February 1, 2012.

summary: 01/31/2012: Gunmen on a motorcycle shot and killed a police officer in Farah city, Farah province, Afghanistan. The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack.
scite1: "Taliban kills cop in Farah city," Afghan Islamic Press (AIP), February 1, 2012.

summary: 01/31/2012: Assailants kidnapped three Peshawar city Electricity Supply Company (PESCO) workers and ten Water and Power Development Authority (WAPDA) workers near an Afghan refugee camp in Matanui area, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, Pakistan. The workers were repairing an electricity pylon when they were kidnapped. The workers were released on May 7, 2013 after 15 months in captivity. No group claimed responsibility for the incident, but police suspected Lashkar-e-Islam (Pakistan).
addnotes: One of the kidnap victims in this incident managed to escape shortly after being abducted. The remaining 12 victims were rescued on May 7, 2013.
scite1: "FACTBOX-Security developments in Pakistan, Jan 31," Reuters News, January 31, 2012.
scite2: "15 months in captivity: Kidnapped PESCO officials, labourers finally return home," The Express Tribune, May 7, 2013.
scite3: "Pakistan: LI blamed for kidnappings," Right Vision News, February 3, 2012.

summary: 02/01/2012: A driver on a motorbike sped through a police checkpoint near Achini Bala area, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, Pakistan. The police then chased after the driver, who escaped. The police captured the driver's bicycle, which was rigged with explosives. No group claimed responsibility, but police attributed the attack to Lashkar-e-Islam (Pakistan).
weapdetail: An explosive device weighing four kilograms and attached to a motorcycle was used in the attack.
scite1: "On the fringes of society: Militants' new tactics - Bombs on motorcycles," The Express Tribune, March 3, 2012.
scite2: "Pakistan: Peshawar police foil terror plot," Right Vision News, February 3, 2012.
scite3: "Foiled terror bid: Police seize explosives-laden bike in Peshawar," The Express Tribune, February 2, 2012.

summary: 01/31/2012: Gunmen attacked a police checkpoint near Muqdadiyah town, Diyala governorate, Iraq. Two people were injured in the attack, including one police officer. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
propcomment: It is unknown if any property was damaged in this attack.
scite1: "FACTBOX-Security developments in Iraq, January 31," Reuters News, January 31, 2012.
scite2: "FACTBOX-Security developments in Iraq, January 31," Reuters News, January 31, 2012.

summary: 01/31/2012: A roadside bomb exploded near a Sahwa Council checkpoint in southern Baghdad city, Baghdad governorate, Iraq. Two militia members were injured in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
propcomment: It is unknown if any property was damaged in this attack.
scite1: "FACTBOX-Security developments in Iraq, January 31," Reuters News, January 31, 2012.

summary: 01/31/2012: Two roadside bombs detonated near Mosul city, Nineveh governorate, Iraq. A police officer and his son were injured in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
weapdetail: Two roadside bombs were used in the attack.
propcomment: It is unknown if any property was damaged in this attack.
scite1: "FACTBOX-Security developments in Iraq, January 31," Reuters News, January 31, 2012.

summary: 01/31/2012: A sticky bomb attached to a police officer's car exploded in eastern Mosul city, Nineveh governorate, Iraq. The police officer was injured in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

summary: 01/31/2012: Twenty-five Chinese workers were abducted from a bus on their way to a cement factory in Arish city, North Sinai governorate, Egypt. The kidnappers took them to their tent and demanded the release of five relatives who were jailed for a suspected role in terrorist incidents in South Sinai between the years 2004 and 2006. The hostages were released 15 hours later with no injuries. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
motive: The kidnappers demanded the release of five relatives who were jailed for a suspected role in terrorist incidents in South Sinai between the years 2004 and 2006.
propcomment: A bus was damaged in this attack.
scite1: "25 Chinese nationals kidnapped taken hostage in Sinai by armed militants," Associated Press Newswires, January 31, 2012.
scite2: "Workers taken hostage," The Times (London), February 1, 2012.
scite3: "Kidnappings of Workers Put Pressure on China," The New York Times, February 1, 2012.

summary: 01/31/2012: Assailants attacked African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM) troops in Jazeera area, Mogadishu city, Banaadir region, Somalia. At least eight people died and 10 were wounded in the attack. No group claimed responsibility, but sources attributed the incident to Al-Shabaab.
scite1: "Somalia: Al-Shabaab Attack TFG Military Base on Outskirts of Mogadishu," BBC World Service, January 31, 2012.

Eighteen people were killed and 12 injured across the four attacks. A Baloch Liberation Army (BLA) spokesperson claimed that the incidents were in response to the killings of Nawab Akbar Bugti's granddaughter and great-granddaughter.

summary: 01/31/2012: An explosive device detonated near government offices in Reykjavik city, Reykjavik North Constituency, Iceland. The explosive device was partially detonated by a robot meant to deactivate it. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
weapdetail: An explosive device consisting of a gasoline container, a percussion cap, and a battery were used in the attack.
propcomment: It is unknown if any property was damaged in this attack.
addnotes: A witness saw a chubby, short, middle-aged man fleeing the scene where the explosive device was found.
scite1: "Icelandic Police Seeking Person Who Planted Bomb Near Government Offices," mbl.is, February 1, 2012.
